Description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the Pennsylvania Department of Environmental Protection (PADEP) and the Allegheny County Health Department (ACHD) have reached a settlement with Shenango Inc. (Shenango) resolving alleged air and water pollution violations at the company's coke manufacturing plant on Neville Island, Allegheny County, Pa. The consent decree requires the company to pay $1.75 million in civil penalties and make significant upgrades to the plant, which is located about five miles north of downtown Pittsburgh.
Info Source: https://archive.epa.gov/epapages/newsroom_archive/newsreleases/1c080d705e4be39385257a4600557a47.html

Agency: Labor Department Wage and Hour Division
Info Source: March 7, 2017 download of a dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division at https://enforcedata.dol.gov/views/data_summary.php
Notes: Date and year are the Findings End Date in the dataset posted by the Wage and Hour Division, which does not provide case opening or closing dates. The company name is the Legal Name provided by the dataset unless that field is blank, in which case the Trade Name is used. The dataset provides only one address and does not indicate whether it is the company headquarters address or the establishment address. The penalty amount is the total of civil monetary penalties and mandated back wages. The original dataset provides a breakdown.

Info Source: https://www.ferc.gov/enforcement/civil-penalties/actions/2013.asp

Description: Detroit Edison agreed to pay $450,000 in penalties and costs as part of the settlement of allegations that it illegally restarted its coal-burning Conners Creek power plant located in downtown Detroit.  Detroit Edison also agreed to convert the plant from coal to cleaner burning natural gas fuel.
Info Source: Michigan Announces Settlement With Detroit Edison Regarding Conners Creek Power Plant, PR Newswire, January 23, 2001 (via Nexis).

Description: DTE Energy agreed to reduce pollution at five coal-fired power plants in southeast Michigan in a settlement with the EPA that also required the company to pay a $1.8 million civil penalty and to undertake a $5.5 million mitigation project to improve air quality in the region by replacing old buses in the area with newer, cleaner ones.
Info Source: https://www.epa.gov/newsreleases/epa-settlement-dte-energy-reduce-air-pollution-southeast-michigan
